get_started.tip_1: Take photos with Seek’s Camera to identify living things all around you.
get_started.tip_2: Learn about the species that have been observed around you with Species Nearby.
get_started.tip_3: Earn badges and raise your level by identifying different types of species and participating in challenges.

inat_signup.permission: You need to be at least 13 years old to create an account.
inat_signup.under_13: Because you’re under 13, we need to get your parent or guardian’s permission before creating an account.
inat_signup.release_photos: Yes, license my photos and observations so scientists can use my data (recommended)!
inat_signup.parent_instructions: We sent your parent or guardian an email with instructions.
inat_signup.linked_account: You’ve linked an iNaturalist account to Seek!
inat_signup.posting_details: You can post observations made in Seek to iNaturalist immediately after you’ve added them to your observations. If you’d like to post them to iNaturalist later, please use the iNaturalist app or website.
inat_signup.observations_1: Your observations in Seek are stored on your device, and are NOT backed up online.
inat_signup.observations_2: Deleting the app will delete all your observations made in Seek.
inat_signup.observations_3: Seek does not sync your observations to other devices.
inat_signup.agree_to_terms: I agree to the <terms>{{terms}}</terms> and <privacy>{{privacy}}</privacy>, and I have reviewed the <guidelines>{{guidelines}}</guidelines>.
inat_signup.store_data: I consent to allow iNaturalist to store and process limited kinds of personal information about me in order to manage my account.
inat_signup.learn_more_about_data_storage: We store personal information like usernames and email addresses in order to manage accounts on this site, and to comply with privacy laws, we need you to check this box to indicate that you consent to this use of personal information. To learn more about what information we collect and how we use it, please see our Privacy Policy and our Terms of Service.
inat_signup.learn_more_about_licensing: Check this box if you want to apply a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial license to uploaded content. This means anyone can copy and reuse your photos and/or observations without asking for permission as long as they give you credit and don't use the works commercially. You can choose a different license or remove the license later, but this is the best license for sharing with researchers.

inat_login.no_worries: No worries. We’ll send password reset instructions to your email.
inat_login.reset_instructions: We sent password reset instructions to your email.

onboarding.onboarding_1: Use Seek’s Camera to identify plants, animals, and fungi
onboarding.onboarding_2: Learn about the organisms all around you
onboarding.onboarding_3: Earn badges for observing different types of species

challenges.april_description:
We are not alone on our planet! Wildlife is always around us whether we notice it or not. In our homes, gardens, towns and cities there are hidden worlds to be discovered. Seek in and around your home, and you may be surprised by how many wild neighbours you find.

Seek out plants, fungi, bugs, birds and animals. Watch out for signs of more elusive life – poo, fur, nests, tracks and webs can all give clues to other creatures that share your home.
challenges.mission_1_may: Temukan 4 burung, mamalia, reptil, amfibi, atau ikan apapun yang berbeda jenis
challenges.may_description: From the deepest jungle to the smallest park, we share our planet with an incredible variety of living things, each adapted to the particular environment in which they live. Seek out a local nature hotspot and see how many different types of living thing you can find. Along the way, you’ll learn what characteristics make these different groups of organisms different from each other!
challenges.congrats: You completed the Our Planet Challenge for {{month}}!
challenges.thanks: Thanks for participating! We can all give nature a helping hand. Follow along with the journey on Netflix’s Our Planet and learn more at ourplanet.com.
challenges.no_completed_challenges: Your completed challenges will appear here.
challenges.no_challenges_in_progress: Start a new challenge below to earn badges!
challenges.no_new_challenges: We’ll let you know when new challenges are available.
challenges.action_april: Check if you live close to a city that's part of the City Nature Challenge, and if so look out for nature recording and identification activities for urban wildlife!
challenges.action_may:
Volunteer your time with local groups that help maintain your local greenspaces.

Share your findings with your family, friends or school community to open their eyes to the wildlife around them.

Organise a litter pick in a local greenspace.
challenges.action_june: Use the resources on ourplanet.com to start a local biodiversity action project in your area to give your local wildlife a helping hand.
challenges.action_november:
Collect seeds from local trees, germinate them in pots and then plant the young trees.

Tell friends or family members about all the things trees do for us.
challenges.action_august:
Plant wildflowers to provide food for pollinators.

Make a ‘bug hotel’ to provide homes for insects in your garden or schoolground by bundling short lengths of pipe together and stuffing each with small twigs and pieces of broken tile.
challenges.action_september:
Keep a record of how much water you use throughout a day. Think how you could cut this down to help reduce the strain on freshwater habitats.

Check local freshwater habitats for litter or other pollution. Could you run a local campaign to protect this precious ecosystem?
challenges.action_october:
Birds need fuel for the long journeys they take to migrate. In winter months leave nuts, seeds and fat balls in your garden to give them a boost.

Plant trees and shrubs that provide berries and roosts for visiting birds.
challenges.action_december: Seek out or start a citizen science project that monitors changing patterns in your local phenology. This data can help scientists understand the impact of climate change and predict what problems this might cause.
challenges.june_description: Every species in a coral reef is important to the rest of the wildlife community, whether it is food for other creatures or a predator that keeps other populations under control. Food chains can be delicate and complex, and this is the case in every ecosystem on our planet. Seek out different levels in your local web of life, and learn how each one enables other species to survive.
challenges.november_description: Humans have always depended on trees and forests for survival. They give us clean air, food, shelter and wood. They take in carbon from the air and lock it away in their wood or the soil. Spending time among trees makes us feel better in mind and body. We need them now even more than ever, and so do a huge number of other living things. Seek out the trees in your local area and feel the benefits for yourself!
challenges.august_description: Big animals of the grassland plains are losing their habitat to farmland, but they are not the only wildlife affected by our food production. Insects populations are declining around our planet, partly because crops replace their habitats and are then sprayed with bug-killing pesticides. We need insect pollinators for our crops and wild plants to flourish, and many amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals depend on insects for food. Seek out the insects around you and show them some love!
challenges.september_description: Freshwater is essential for all life on land, and freshwater habitats are home to more than 10 per cent of all known animals and almost half of all known fish species. Rivers, streams and lakes allow wildlife to travel vast distances to complete their life cycles. Seek out ponds, streams, rivers and lakes in your area and see what freshwater species you can spot.
challenges.october_description: The seas cover vast areas of our planet, and without modern technology humans would find it very difficult to cross these huge expanses. Many bird species, however, do exactly this every year. Millions of birds migrate from one country to another to escape cold weather and to find food. Keeping track of when wildlife migrates can help us understand how climate change is affecting the natural world. Seek birds visiting your local area and find out where else they spend their time.
challenges.december_description: Climate change is not just affecting the frozen worlds at our planet’s poles. Rising temperatures and changing weather patterns can cause species to move out of habitats that become uncomfortable and into areas that couldn’t support them before. It can also mean that changes linked to seasons (known as ‘phenology’) such as leaf fall, bud burst and flowering start to take place at different times. This may cause problems for other species that are hard to predict. Seek out your local plant life and see how your local environment may be changing.
challenges.mission_2_june: Temukan 3 belalang, jangkrik, belalang pelahap, kupu-kupu, ngengat, ulat, atau mamalia pemakan tumbuhan (herbivora)
challenges.mission_3_june: Temukan 2 arachnida, belalang sembah, atau mamalia pemakan daging yang berbeda (karnivora)
challenges.mission_1_september: Find any 10 different species from: dragonflies, amphibians, fish, ducks, mosses, ferns, water lilies, bulrushes, or cattails

challenges.photographer_december: Photo © Sophie Lanfear, Netflix / Silverback Films

challenges.no_species_nearby: We found no species nearby in this challenge that you haven't already observed

Learn more about this species here:
results.learn_more_no_location: Pelajari lebih lanjut tentang spesies ini di:

results.sorry:
Sorry about that, Seek is still learning!

You can try a different angle, zoom in, or try to get a clearer shot of the organism.
results.common_ancestor:
But Seek couldn’t identify the exact species.

You can try a different angle, zoom in, or try to get a clearer shot of the organism.
results.believe: We believe this is a member of
results.genus: We believe this is a member of the genus
results.family: We believe this is a member of the family
results.order: We believe this is a member of the order

results.resighted: Kamu melihat kembali spesies yang sama!
results.post_inat: If you took the original photo of the organism, you can help train Seek on this species by posting to iNaturalist, where the community will help identify it and improve future versions.
results.yes: Yes, remove it from my observations
results.error_server: Sorry, we couldn't score this image. Please check your internet connection and try again.
results.error_image: Sorry, we couldn't process your image. Please check your internet connection and try again.
results.error_species: Sorry, we couldn't fetch species details for this image. Please check your internet connection and try again.
results.error_location: You won't be able to view range maps, explore species nearby, or post this observation to iNaturalist. If you enable location in Seek, you'll be able to view detailed information about your observations and contribute to citizen science. Your location will not be published unless you post to iNaturalist.

results.error_gps: Seek can't detect your GPS location. Your observation has been saved, but without location, you won't be able to view detailed information such as range maps. Try moving to a place where you can see the sky and check that your device's location services are turned on.
results.error_timeout: Your location took too long to retrieve. Your observation has been saved, but without location, you won't be able to view detailed information such as range maps. Please try again later.
results.nothing_nearby: Looks like there haven’t been many species observed nearby in this taxon! Try taking another photo or posting it to iNaturalist.

camera.label: Kamera
camera.scan: Keep scanning the environment for organisms to identify!
camera.scan_class: Try different angles till you can get the identification to species!
camera.scan_species: Itu dia! Sekarang ambil gambarnya untuk menambahkan spesies ini ke pengamatanmu.
camera.error_permissions: We need access to the camera to help you identify species!
camera.error_gallery: We need access to your photo library to save photos you take!

camera.error_device: Sorry, the device you are using is not supported

camera.error_selected_photos: If your permissions are set to 'Selected Photos', you may need to restart Seek or visit iOS Settings > Seek > Photos > Selected Photos to choose which photos to display here.

camera_help.title: Kamera Seek
camera_help.explanation_1: Each dot on the Seek Camera represents a taxonomic level, from kingdom down to species. This system is how scientists classify living things.
camera_help.explanation_2: Point the camera at living things around you, and take a picture once the meter fills up to species.
camera_help.how_works:
Seek’s identification model works directly using the tree of life.

Each dot on the identification bar represents a taxonomic level on the tree of life. As Seek is able to confidently identify the species you’re looking at at each level, it will add another dot to the bar. When the organism is identified to species, take a photo!
camera_help.tips:
Seek is best at identifying photos with good lighting and a clear shot of the species, so try different angles until you get the right shot.

Seek is still learning, so if the dots can’t seem to fill up all the way, you’re probably looking at an organism that’s not commonly found in iNaturalist’s database. You can post observations to iNaturalist to help Seek learn to identify these better!
camera_help.tip_1: Always be aware of your surroundings and stay safe!
camera_help.tip_2: Jangan memakan apapun yang kamu temukan di alam liar.
camera_help.tip_4: Respect other living things by not harassing or touching them. Some may sting or bite.

species_detail.range_about: Peta pengamatan spesies ini yang terlihat di iNaturalist.
species_detail.taxonomy_about: Klasifikasi organisme di setiap tingkat pada pohon kehidupan.
species_detail.inat_obs_about: Jumlah total pengamatan iNaturalist yang dibuat tentang spesies ini di dekatmu dan di seluruh dunia.
species_detail.monthly_obs_about: Pengamatan di seluruh dunia berdasarkan bulan untuk organisme ini.
species_detail.endangered_about: This species is in danger of going extinct throughout all or a significant portion of its range.
species_detail.endemic_about: This species naturally occurs in this area and isn’t found anywhere else.
species_detail.native_about: This species naturally occurs in this area and was not brought here by humans.
species_detail.threatened_about: This species is likely to become in danger of extinction in the future.
species_detail.introduced_about: This species was brought to this area by humans, and doesn’t naturally occur here.
species_detail.similar_about: Organisms commonly misidentified as this species.
species_detail.similar_no_species: Looks like there haven’t been many similar species observed nearby!
species_detail.you: Hey look, it’s you! Get outside and find some wild species to learn even more about them.
species_detail.internet_error: We need the internet to generate the species detail screen. Tap to try again.
species_detail.no_photos_found: No photos found for this species.

about.joint_initiative: iNaturalist adalah inisiatif gabungan dari California Academy of Sciences dan National Geographic Society.
about.original: Seek pada awalnya dibuat dengan dukungan HHMI Tangled Bank Studios dan ditingkatkan dengan dukungan dari Our Planet di Netflix dan WWF.
about.inat_team: Abhas Misraraj, Amanda Bullington, Alex Shepard, Scott Loarie, Ken-ichi Ueda, Carrie Seltzer, Tony Iwane, Patrick Leary, and Yaron Budowski. Special thanks to Visipedia and the iNaturalist community.
about.help: For help with Seek, please email help+seek@inaturalist.org.
about.translations: We are grateful for the translation assistance provided by the crowdin.com community, especially: Abdelghani Hourani, Carnifex, cgalindo, Daniele Seglie, Eduardo Martínez, Édson Souza Jr., Galder Gonzalez Larrañaga, Gideon Wentink, Johan Liljeblad, katunchik, Kiara Suzuki, Lekkim, Marcel Hospers, Martin Reith, Monica Nieminen, Nicolae Liviu, Nuwan Wijayaweera, saariko, Sakatur, Sebastian Jasiński, TheKakarinka, Wouter Koch, and Yulia Lygina.
about.join_crowdin: To join the Seek translation team, please visit https://crowdin.com/project/seek

posting_status.posting_to_inat_background: MENGUNGGAH KE INATURALIST DI LATAR BELAKANG
posting_status.posting_to_inat_background_description:
Posting to iNaturalist will continue in the background while Seek is open.

You can check the status of uploads on the home screen.
posting_status.no_internet_description:
Your observation has not been uploaded to iNaturalist because you're not connected to the internet.

You can upload your observation from the home screen once you have internet.

posting_help.id_description:
As you upload your observation, you can identify the species to whatever taxa you are most confident- from a class such as reptiles, down to a species, like Western Bluebird. After your observation is posted to iNaturalist, our community will help identify the species.

You can also choose to add optional notes to your observation here.
posting_help.date_description: Every observation on iNaturalist is associated with a certain date and location. This way, we can clearly see a global picture of how a species is doing worldwide over time.
posting_help.open: Other users on iNaturalist will be able to see where this species was observed, and scientists can use this data for research.
posting_help.obscured: The exact location of this observation will be hidden from other users on iNaturalist, and instead expanded to a larger area. (The locations of all threatened and endangered species is automatically obscured)
posting_help.closed: The location of this observation will not be shared with other users on iNaturalist.
posting_help.no: This is an organism that naturally occurs in the wild, and wasn’t brought to this location by humans.
posting_help.yes: This organism was placed in this location by humans. This applies to things like garden plants, pets, and zoo animals.
posting_help.addendum: *Adding observations to projects is not supported in Seek. If you’d like to add your observations to a project, please do so on iNaturalist.org or use the iNaturalist app.

delete.description: Do you want to remove this species from your observations? This may affect your challenges and badges.

warning.tip_1: Always be aware of your surroundings, stay safe, and don’t trespass.
warning.tip_2: Jangan memakan apapun yang kamu temukan di alam liar.
warning.tip_3: Respect other living things by not harassing or touching them. Some may sting or bite.
warning.tip_4: Anak-anak mungkin memerlukan pengawasan orang tua.

accessibility.open_posting_help: Buka postingan ke layar bantuan iNaturalist

review.title: Nilai aplikasi ini
review.rate: Jika kamu menyukai aplikasi ini, tolong luangkan waktu untuk menilainya di Play Store. Terima kasih atas dukungan Anda!

settings.donate_description: Menikmati Seek? Menyumbanglah ke iNaturalist! Kami tergantung pada donasi dari orang-orang sepertimu untuk tetap menyediakan aplikasi secara gratis.
settings.auto_capture: Ambil gambar secara otomatis ketika proses identifikasi telah menemukan spesies.
settings.seasonality_option_1: Display seasonality based on worldwide iNaturalist observations
settings.seasonality_option_2: Display seasonality based on iNaturalist observations near my current location (species not found near my location will have no seasonality)
settings.donate_ios: Please visit the following link to make a donation to Seek:

seek_challenges.header: You completed the Seek Challenge for {{date}}!
seek_challenges.text: Thanks for participating in the global challenge! Seek is here to help you connect to all the species surrounding us. Get outside, explore, and learn about the nature all around you!
seek_challenges.completed: You completed the challenge and earned the challenge badge!
seek_challenges.april_2020_description:
April 2020 is the one-year anniversary of the release of the new Seek by iNaturalist! In the past year, we’ve grown a lot and have helped over a million people feel more connected to the world around them. Nature is all around you, you simply need to Seek it out!

To start off our next round of challenges, see if you can find 10 species you haven’t observed yet.
seek_challenges.action_april_2020:
April is Citizen Science Month! You can contribute to scientific understand of biodiversity as a citizen scientist by posting your Seek observations to iNaturalist.

If you are 13 or older (or with parental permission), you can make an iNaturalist account and post observations to iNaturalist to share your observations with a broader community, including scientists!
seek_challenges.may_2020_description: You don't need to go far to find nature all around you. Even in just your backyard or neighborhood, you can find plants, birds, and insects that share your space.
seek_challenges.action_may_2020: Use Seek's Species Nearby on the home screen to learn about all the birds, plants, and insects that have been observed around you and check out their species pages. What time of year are they most observed? Then try exploring somewhere new: what species could you find near Cairo, Paris, or Jakarta?
seek_challenges.mission_1_june_2020: Find 2 plants in the order Asterales (Asters, Bellflowers, Fanflowers, and Allies)
seek_challenges.mission_2_june_2020: Find 3 birds in the order Passeriformes (Perching Birds)
seek_challenges.mission_3_june_2020: Find 1 insect in the order Coleoptera (Beetles)
seek_challenges.june_2020_description: Nature is resilient and all around us. From cities to farmland, plants and animals find a way to thrive. Even in urban areas, plants, birds, and insects coexist with us.
seek_challenges.action_june_2020: Did you know you can view scientific names instead of common names in the Seek camera? Go to the settings page from the menu to change the display from common names to scientific names!
seek_challenges.mission_2_july_2020: Find any 3 aquatic birds from the orders Anseriformes, Charadriiformes, Coraciiformes, Gaviiformes, Gruiformes, Pelecaniformes, Phoenicopteriformes, Podicipediformes, Procellariiformes, Sphenisciformes, & Suliformes
seek_challenges.july_2020_description: Rivers are a hub for biodiversity. Supporting everything from microinvertebrates to large vertebrates, rivers help the organisms around them thrive.
seek_challenges.action_july_2020: When you're near a body of water, what organisms do you notice? What species are swimming in the water? What species are flying above it? Are there organisms in the water you might not be able to see?
seek_challenges.mission_1_aug_2020: Find 2 plants in the order Lamiales (Mints, Plantains, Olives, and Allies)
seek_challenges.mission_2_aug_2020: Find 1 plant from the family Asteraceae (Sunflowers, Daisies, Asters, and Allies)
seek_challenges.mission_3_aug_2020: Find 1 plant from the order Rosales (Roses, Elms, Figs, and Allies)
seek_challenges.aug_2020_description: Pollinators give us foods we eat and flowers we enjoy! By moving pollen between different plants using their bodies, pollinators help many kinds of plants reproduce.
seek_challenges.action_aug_2020: Pay attention to the pollinators around you. Are there bees or butterflies visiting the flowers in your garden or neighborhood?
seek_challenges.sept_2020_description: Herbivores are animals that are adapted to feed only on plants. Herbivorous mammals often have complex digestive systems that enable them to break down large amounts of plant material. For example, cows actually have 4 stomachs to break down the plants they consume. Other mammals specialize in fruit (fruit bats) or seeds (squirrels). Many insects are also adapted to eat different parts of plants, such as caterpillars that eat leaves or plant hoppers that suck sap from stems.
seek_challenges.action_sept_2020:
Do some research on how meat consumption impacts the environment. What steps can you take to reduce your own impact?

Alternative: What kinds of plants do you eat? What parts of the plant do they come from? Can you find out what kinds of animals also like to eat those plants?
seek_challenges.oct_2020_description: Scavengers and decomposers are essential to life on our planet. Fungi are decomposers that can break down dead tissue such as wood and leaves. Many types of animals such as vultures, isopods, and some snails can eat dead plants or animals. They help to recycle nutrients so they are available for new growth.
seek_challenges.action_oct_2020: Find out what kind of decomposers and scavengers live in the areas around you. What are they consuming? Do they always eat the same kinds of things?
seek_challenges.mission_1_nov_2020: Find 1 bird in the order Columbiformes (Pigeons and Doves)
seek_challenges.mission_2_nov_2020: Find 1 plant in the order Fabales (Legumes, Milkworts, and Allies)
seek_challenges.nov_2020_description: Many species have evolved to adapt to human environments as our populations have grown worldwide. Even in dense urban areas, we can find birds, plants, and insects living among us.
seek_challenges.action_nov_2020: What are common wild species you see in your area? Are these species native, invasive, or introduced? If introduced, see if you can find out how these species got here.
seek_challenges.mission_1_dec_2020: Find any 3 vertebrates (birds, mammals, reptiles, amphibians, and fish)
seek_challenges.dec_2020_description: Ecosystems function with organisms of all different types and niches. Producers, consumers, and decomposers work together to balance the ecosystem.
seek_challenges.action_dec_2020: Explore how different types of ecosystems function with organisms distributed across the food chain. How are they different in different parts of the world and in different biomes?

replace_photo.description: Apakah kamu ingin mengganti foto dari pengamatanmu yang dilihat kembali?

social.error: Tolong memeriksa kembali apakah kamu sudah memasang aplikasi Facebook.

natgeo_challenges.mar_2021_description:
We are kicking off four months of National Geographic Society-sponsored challenges focused on understanding how we depend on and affect the natural world.

Nature is all around us, and time spent in nature helps to build health and happiness. If possible, we encourage you to pick a place such as a local park, protected area, or your yard that you visit every month as part of your explorations with Seek. For this month's mission: find any ten species that make you feel happy!

To find resources to help you use Seek and learn more about biodiversity, visit NatGeoEd.org/BioBlitz.
natgeo_challenges.mar_2021_action: Spend some time getting reacquainted with, or learning how to use, Seek. Visit the home screen to see what species live nearby. Let us know your favorite local plant or animal, or one you’d really like to observe using #NatGeoSeekChallenge on Twitter!
natgeo_challenges.mar_2021_photographer: Photo by: Tom Matthews / National Geographic
natgeo_challenges.apr_2021_mission_1: Temukan 2 moluska apapun (kerang, siput, bekicot, siput laut) atau krustasea (teritip, kepiting, lobster, pillbug)
natgeo_challenges.apr_2021_description: Climate change, species loss, and plastic pollution are three of the greatest challenges our planet currently faces and all are driven by human activity. This year's theme for Earth Day (April 22nd) is "Restore our Earth." We all need to work together to build a more sustainable future for both communities and wildlife—your individual actions can help to make a difference!
natgeo_challenges.apr_2021_action: One of the most widespread human impacts on ecosystems is trash. As you explore nature this month, pay attention to the litter you see and think about where it may have come from. Make a list of things you could do at home to reduce the waste that your family generates, and share this list with the rest of your family - and with us using #NatGeoSeekChallenge on Twitter!
natgeo_challenges.apr_2021_photographer: Photo by: Enric Sala / National Geographic
natgeo_challenges.may_2021_description: Healthy ecosystems provide us with many different benefits, including cleaning our water and air, storing carbon, and providing habitat to support biodiversity. Some species—such as lichens, moss and odonates (dragonflies and damselflies) are known to be indicators of ecological health. When you see these species it's a good sign that your ecosystem is healthy!
natgeo_challenges.may_2021_action: Healthy ecosystems have important benefits on our own health and well-being. Time spent in nature can help people recover from stress, improve their mood and think more clearly. Find a peaceful spot in nature and spend an hour focusing on the sights, sounds, smells, and textures around you. Write down some of your observations. How does this time spent in nature make you feel? Share a photo of your spot using #NatGeoSeekChallenge on Twitter!
natgeo_challenges.may_2021_photographer: Photo by: Jim Richardson / National Geographic
natgeo_challenges.june_2021_mission_2: Find 1 plant in the class Pinopsida (Conifers)
natgeo_challenges.june_2021_mission_3: Find 1 plant from the subphylum Angiospermae (Flowering Plants)
natgeo_challenges.june_2021_mission_5: Temukan 2 vertebrata (burung, mamalia, amfibi, reptil, ikan)
natgeo_challenges.june_2021_description: All of us, regardless of our age or experience, can have a positive impact on biodiversity conservation. For example, we can help take care of a particular place like our own yard, a protected area, or a local park. Protecting nature starts by learning about the plants, fungi and animals that are in the places that you care about. Your challenge this month is to look in your yard or a local park and take an inventory of as much biodiversity as you can.
natgeo_challenges.june_2021_action: This month, focus on learning something about each species you document, including which ones are native and which are introduced.  Reflect on all of your observations over the past four months— what differences have you noticed in biodiversity and the human footprint across this period and across the different places you've explored? Identify something you can commit to doing to help make a local place (such as your yard or a park) healthier for native species. Write down your goal, take a photo of it, and share it with us at #NatGeoSeekChallenge on Twitter!
natgeo_challenges.june_2021_photographer: Photo by: Keith Ladzinski / National Geographic

about_inat.inat_value_prop_3: Add, edit, and manage all your observations in one place
about_inat.inat_value_prop_4: Follow people and see what your friends are observing
about_inat.get_started_by_downloading_inat:
Get started by downloading the iNaturalist app or visiting inaturalist.org.

Already have an iNaturalist account? Log in to Seek with your existing account!
about_inat.we_think_youll_like_inat: We think you’ll really like iNaturalist.
about_inat.log_in_to_post_observations: Masuklah untuk mengunggah pengamatan Seek ke iNaturalist!
about_inat.inat_is_an_online_community: iNaturalist is an online community for naturalists
about_inat.inat_bullet_1: iNaturalist observations are public and help contribute to science
about_inat.inat_bullet_2: Each observation includes your username, date, and location of the observation
about_inat.inat_bullet_3: The iNaturalist community helps to identify and confirm observations
about_inat.seek_is_an_id_app: Seek is an ID app that helps anyone learn about the species around them
about_inat.seek_bullet_1: Seek observations stay on your device
about_inat.seek_bullet_2: No personally identifiable information is collected from logged out users
about_inat.seek_bullet_3: Identifications do not leave your device or require internet to work, but aren’t confirmed by the iNaturalist community
about_inat.everyday_obs_help_scientists: Everyday observations made by naturalists like you can help scientists learn about where and when organisms are found, and even lead to new discoveries!
about_inat.faq_1: You must be 13+ or have a parent’s permission to create an iNaturalist account
about_inat.faq_2: Seek and iNaturalist use the same identification model, but only iNaturalist observations are confirmed by the community

x_observations_posted_to_inat.zero: {{count}} observations posted to iNaturalist with Seek
x_observations_posted_to_inat.one: {{count}} observation posted to iNaturalist with Seek
x_observations_posted_to_inat.two: {{count}} observations posted to iNaturalist with Seek
x_observations_posted_to_inat.few: {{count}} observations posted to iNaturalist with Seek
x_observations_posted_to_inat.many: {{count}} observations posted to iNaturalist with Seek
x_observations_posted_to_inat.other: {{count}} observations posted to iNaturalist with Seek

about_inat.logged_in_bullet_1: You can post observations to iNaturalist by clicking 'Post to iNaturalist' after you make a Seek observation
about_inat.logged_in_bullet_2: Use the iNaturalist app or website to view notifications of identifications, comments, and other activity on your observations
about_inat.logged_in_bullet_3: Your Seek observations are NOT backed up to iNaturalist. Deleting Seek will delete all the observations on your device.
about_inat.upload_and_track_obs_using_inat:
Upload and keep track of your observations using the iNaturalist app or visiting inaturalist.org.

Thanks for being part of this community!

seek_2021_challenges.august_2021_description: Predators are animals that hunt and consume other animals. But you don’t need to go far to find them! Centipedes, spiders, and many other insects and arachnids are probably hunting for smaller prey animals just outside your window—or even indoors. Even most Lady Beetles are predators!
seek_2021_challenges.august_2021_action: Think about the types of predators you found. What kinds of prey animals do they eat? How do they find, catch, and consume prey?
seek_2021_challenges.september_2021_description: Seasons are changing! Each year there are two equinoxes: in March and September. On the day of the equinox, there will be almost exactly 12 hours of daylight and 12 hours of night everywhere in the world. As the length of the days change, plants and animals respond by changing their growth or behavior.
seek_2021_challenges.september_2021_action: Have there been any extreme weather events near you recently? How did plants, animals, and fungi respond? Try to find past weather data for this month in your area. What kind of changes have occurred and how do you think that might impact the organisms that live there?
seek_2021_challenges.october_2021_description: Did you know that not all arachnids are spiders? In addition to spiders, mites and ticks, harvestmen (also known as “daddy longlegs”), and even tiny, overlooked pseudoscorpions can be found on all inhabited continents. Other less well-known arachnids like scorpions, whipscorpions, tailless whipscorpions, and solifuges are generally found in warmer and/or drier parts of the world.
seek_2021_challenges.october_2021_action: Think about the kinds of arachnids you found. How would you describe their habitats? Were any of them found in the same habitat?
